doc.title: Daily Economic Briefing (Maia G Crook)
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-09/J.P. Morgan LatAm FTM 29 Aug 25J.P. Morgan LatAm FTM 29 Aug 25_2025-08-09

passages.text: LatAm Bottlers (Lucas Ferreira)

We expect 2H25 volumes for LatAm Bottlers to improve and still bring high- single- digit to low- double- digit EBITDA growth in 2H for most peers despite a persistently challenging weather pattern in Mexico and Brazil and a still sluggish consumption environment in key regions. Moreover, we believe market expectations, especially for KOF but also AC, largely reflect what should be still sluggish 3Q. As we revise our estimates for the Mx Bottlers, we find valuation enticing having underperformed the Mexbol by \(21\% /5\%\) pp (KOF/AC) respectively YTD and trading on avg at a \(15\%\) discount to the broader Mx Consumer peers, which are likely exposed to similar demand side risks but with a less resilient pricing power (here) while remaining with a superior 5yr EPS CAGR. In the case of Andina, we see limited room for further re- rating, trading at a \(10\%\) premium vs Mx Peers with similar EPS CAGR while it has slightly outperformed its local trading index (IPSA). Compared to consensus, our EBITDA estimates for this and next year for KOF are \(2 / 3\%\) ahead vs BBG consensus but mostly in line for AC and Andina.
Mexico Retail (Joseph Giordano/Froylan Mendez)

Key consumption leading indicators do not show a clear picture of an inflection point into 2H25E beyond the seasonal recovery from lapping a tough comparable base from the pre- electoral period in 1H25. Remittances, job creation and real wage mass continued to lose momentum into July while ANTAD (here) reading was also underwhelming. With this in mind, we believe 2H25E will be another chapter of the tale of several Mexicos (here) depicting a more selective, savvy and price/promotion driven consumer with Very distinct dynamics among consumer profiles and consumption occasions. Our top sector pick remains Ow- rated (TBBB), benefiting from a format gaining consumer share and occupying market white spaces. Among traditional supermarkets, we prefer N- rated Chedraui, which after a rally YTD trades mostly in line with Walnex and is still expected to outperform the latter in 2H, with limited but welcomed gross margin expansion, despite the industry's lack of pricing power. For N- rated FEMSA, our mildest 2H recovery view is due to the convenience format needing stronger economic acceleration to pick up. Still, a potential increase in buyback activity could be a trigger for the stock in the absence of a pick up in SS. Liverpool's 2H SSS is expected to decelerate, on top of what appears to be a negative contribution from Nordstrom result already in Liverpool's bottom line, while we maintain a \(30\%\) governance discount.
Brazil Autos (Guilherme Mendes/Marcelo Motta)

Earlier this week, we hosted a meeting with Fernando Scatena, CFO for South America at Stellantis (STLAM IM, OW- rated by Jose Asumendi). The discussions centered around recent changes in the IPI tax, the competitive landscape, and credit conditions, among other topics. The main takeaways were: (i) The company expects to sustain profitability levels through an

assertive production mix, cost- cutting initiatives, and vertical integration; (ii) Ahead of the implementation of the new IPI tax program (IPI Verde), Stellantis is not implementing bonuses and discounts out of the ordinary; (iii) Automakers and car rental companies should continue to sustain a mutually beneficial relationship, with discounts and payment conditions perceived as sustainable. We view Brazilian Car Rental players trading at 7.1x P/E 2026e, and Auto Parts trading at 5.1x EV/EBITDA 2026e
Banco Macro (Yuri R Fernandes) (BMA, N)

Macro reported ARS 156bn net income post OCI ( \(\sim 12\%\) ROE), rebounding \(247\%\) Q- o- Q. This implies US \(130\mathrm{mn}\) net income or a \(7\%\) beat vs. our estimates. While NPL ratio deteriorated \(+60\) bps Q- o- Q, this was better than peers: SUPV \(+70\) bps to \(2.7\%\) BBAR up 90bps to \(2.3\%\) and GGAL \(+190\) bps to \(5.5\%\) . Thus, we have a neutral first take. Main highlights: (i) NII (with securities & other) was mostly in line vs. JPM with NIM expansion; (ii) but Banco Macro has a worsening in ARS LDR increasing some 6 p.p sequentially to \(97.5\%\) as ARS loans grew \(13\%\) Q- o- Q vs. ARS deposits up only \(1\%\) ; and (iii) with NPL worsening the coverage ratio dropped 23 p.p to \(140\%\) . All in all, a small beat on better fees, improved efficiency and net monetary results as inflation has been tracking lower. We usually see Macro as a more defensive player given its higher capitalization ( \(\sim 30\%\) tier 1) and historical higher exposure to the public servants which is driving more stability in the current environment (i.e. worsening retail NPL and challenging delinquency). Macro is trading at \(\sim 1.1\) x last reported P/BV (LC) or \(\sim 0.85x\) forward book.
